p.seg: The 50th year of the King's reign,
being unquiet (=sick),
the king was concerned about the long period of time already spent [the prolonged sickness and the short time remaining to him],
worrying that he might fail (to pass on) the precious lesson.
On the wuzi day (the 25th day of the cycle), he washed his face.
On the jichou day (the 26th day of the cycle), at dawn [...]
The king said thus:
"Fa, (my son), my sickness is very serious,
I worry of not passing on my lesson to you.
In the past my predecessors transmitted their treasure [=their lesson],
one must receive it and memorize it by recitation.
Now my sickness is (already) very severe,
I worry that I will not (be able to) recite it to the end (for you to memorize),
(so) you should receive it and write it down.
Be diligent and restrain yourself!
In the past Shun was for a long time a man of low status,
tilling the Li hill with is own hands,
anxious to obtain 'the middle',
examining (diligently) his own intent
so as not to run counter the many wishes of the ten thousand surnames [=the people].
his (intent) was applied towards those above and below him, far and near,
(so to) change positions (=manage the officials?) and set up standards,
to evaluate things (under the influence) of the principles Yin and Yang (=the miriad things),
so that they all be suitable and none would be in opposition (to him).
After Shun had obtained 'the middle',
in (his) words he did not change facts or names,
in (his) person he became ever more compliant and sincere,
diligent and perseverant,
thereby establishing the three grand virtues.
Emperor Yao deemed him excellent,
and he [=Shun] therefore received his succession.
Oh, be diligent about it!
In the past Wei (Shang Jia Wei) borrowed 'the middle' from the (duke of the) river He (?),
to get vengeance against You Yi,
and You Yi (thereby) paid for his transgression,
while Wei was unharmed,
and then he returned 'the middle' to the (duke of the) river He.
Wei held to it ['the middle'] and did not forget it,
passing it on to his descendants,
until Tang the successful,
respectful, compliant and tireless,
who thereby received the great mandate (of overthrowing the Xia).
"Oh, Fa, (my son), be diligent!
It is not long that I have heard about it (=since I acceded to the throne),
and my life will not last much longer.
Now you should be diligent, compliant and relentless,
surely there wil be advancement,
(even though) I will not reach to (see) you personally receive the great mandate (overthrowing the Shang) .
Be diligent, restrain yourself!
The days are too short,
neither are the nights long (=use your time wisely).
